text: - [Vinod] I'm Vinod.
Now we are going to know
about Amazon CloudWatch Internet Monitor.

Internet Monitor is a
feature of Amazon CloudWatch

that helps you monitor
internet availability

and performance metrics between
your AWS-hosted applications
and the application end users.

Internet Monitor provides
a weather map on top

of collections of global
monitors operated by AWS.

We get a broad global
view of internet weather
with the ability to zoom in
and understand the performance metrics
and availability issues
that are affecting a particular city.

This map displays internet
weather of the entire world

and this map is accessible
from all AWS regions
and there is no charge to use it.
We will set up Internet Monitor.
Select create monitor, provide a name.
Next, we select our resources to monitor.

For this demo, I have deployed
applications in us-east-2
inside a VPC.
If you have CloudFront distributions,
we can choose that too.
We can also choose network load balancers,
Amazon workspace directories.
Next, we need to select the percentage
of traffic to be monitored.

Either we can choose entire
traffic to be monitored
by selecting 100%

or choose a portion of
traffic by specifying 99,
95 or even 1%.
Other way is to select city-networks.
By default, 100 city-networks are included
in free tier monitoring
across all monitors in the account.
Maximum we can choose is for 100,000.

For this example, I'm
choosing 50,000 city-networks.
You'll be charged based on city-networks.

If you're unsure, you can start
with 1% traffic percentage
and 100 city-networks
and then adjust the city-networks

as you find a baseline
in traffic monitoring.

Or you can start with a
higher city-network number,

monitor for a couple of hours
and then adjust the number.
Now we select Create Monitor.
Initially, it'll go to pending status.
After some time, it goes to active.
If you have multiple applications
or if you wanted to monitor portions

of applications separately, you
can create multiple monitors
with different set of resources.

I'm selecting previously
created PetSite_Monitor
with same 50,000 city-networks.
In the overview page,
we get quick insights into health scores,
traffic overview and latest events.
We can also choose different timelines

and see the latest events
within that window.

I navigate to Traffic
Insights tab, wait a bit
to collect all latest details.

Here we get information
around the locations
and internet traffic graphs.

Next to that, we have Historical
Explorer that shows details

of performance scores, availability
score, bytes transfered,
and round-trip time.
At the bottom, we get a list
of recent events during the time window.
Now we go back to Traffic Insights tab.
We can toggle between graph view

and table view to see
your top client locations.

We can also export the
data to CSV or JSON.
When we scroll down,
we see traffic optimization suggestions.
Now I choose checkbox for show CloudFront
and see detailed suggestions.
In the internet traffic graph section,

we can see total traffic
percentage being monitored.

In the dropdown, I can select
different traffic percentages.
As you can see, 100% of traffic
is being monitored by 131 city-networks.

I can also choose update
monitoring coverage

and if I pick 99%, I see
that 68 city-networks
are contributing to that

and also see the amount of
spend that I'll be having
for this particular coverage.
To save cost, I'll pick 99%
and I'll choose update monitor coverage.
Internet Monitor also provides metrics
and we can see them in CloudWatch metrics.
I choose all metrics
and I choose PetSite_Monitor,

and here I see all the
measurement sources.

I choose them and as you
can see, I get the details

around the performance
score, availability score.

We can also create alarms
for getting alerted
if scores for availability

or performance fall down
below certain threshold.
Thanks for listening in.
